== Exercise: Using preferences in the life cycle class
=== Target In this exercise you store the last logged in user name in the preferences.
You continue to use the dialog which you created in
. In this exercise you modify your life cycle handler so that the previously entered user is displayed again in the password dialog.
=== Dependency
The `@Preference` annotation is provided by the `org.eclipse.e4.core.di.extensions` plug-in. Ensure that you have entered a dependency to this plug-in in the _MANIFEST.MF_ file of your application plug-in. If you followed the previous exercises correctly this dependency is already entered.
=== Create interface for the preference constants
Create the `com.example.e4.rcp.todo.preferences` package and the following interface in this package.
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="../examples/preferences/PreferenceConstants.java[] ----
=== Using preferences in the life cycle class
This exercise is optional.
Extend the `Manager` class to get the user preference injected during application startup.
<xi:include xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XInclude" parse="text" href="../examples/preferences/Manager.java[] ----
=== Validate life cycle handling Start your application and enter a user. Stop and the application and start the application again. The login dialog should display the last entered user.
If persisting the user does not work, you potentially have an incorrect setting in your launch configuration.
Ensure that the _Clear_ flag in the menu: Project Run Configurations...
is not set. Otherwise your preference data is deleted during the start of the application.
